Award.AwardTitle: Riding the Road Map to Transfer

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
West Los Angeles College's "Riding the Road Map to Transfer" (RRMT) program is providing approximately 78 S-STEM scholarships over five years to students in biology, chemistry, geology/earth sciences, and physics/astronomy. The goal of RRMT is to use high impact activities to engage, graduate, and transfer highly motivated, predominately African American and Latino STEM students. RRMT student scholars are (1) receiving financial aid, transfer and career counseling, faculty mentoring, and presentations by invited scientists; (2) participating in internships; (3) developing e-portfolios; and (4) building their knowledge of research techniques, methodologies, and the application of science through undergraduate research projects and targeted field experiences.

RRMT's intellectual merit includes: (a) drawing students from and exploring the relationships between the four basic broad disciplines while reinforcing fundamental scientific principles and (b) engaging with a diverse faculty from different disciplines through laboratory exercises, outside-of-class experimental and research investigations, mentoring, exposure to scientific meetings, and interactions with science in the workplace.

The broader impact of RRMT is the direct enhancement of the diversity of the STEM student body at regional universities and the larger STEM workforce in Los Angeles. RRMT leverages the college's TRIO SSS, EOC, and UB programs to recruit and support talented, motivated, and financially needy minority students into STEM fields. Project findings are being used to expand the college's understanding of how to support low-income underrepresented STEM students and are made available to the larger STEM academic community through the project website and presentations at regional and national meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overall Program Evaluation:

The RRMT program has been a monumental success. It has been well received and supported by faculty and administration. Project activities are announced to the college community as a whole significantly raising the profile of the Science Division and the student-scholars. With the Directed Studies courses, the guest lecturers, and RRMT student presentations, RRMT has increased awareness among STEM students of not only RRMT and the opportunities it provides but also of STEM in general as a field of study.about the basic equipment used in cell culture, including the proper operation of a biosafety cabinet and cell incubators. Students also learnt how to prepare and sterilize numerous kinds of culture media for the growth of eukaryotic cells. Culture techniques such as cell splitting, cell counting and cell transfection were introduced and students were given cultures of cells to culture. Students performed rudimentary analysis of their cell cultures, including preparing a cell lysate and analysis of that lysis through gel electrophoresis. Biology 285 was another Directed Studies course that introduced students to Techniques in DNA. The course was designed to give students hands-on experience in the isolation and manipulation of DNA in a laboratory setting. Students learnt how to transform bacteria with recombinant DNA, expand these bacteria and isolate the introduced DNA. Students further learnt about the analysis of DNA using restriction enzymes and agarose gel electrophoresis, DNA amplification through PCR and the creation and introduction of recombinant plasmids. In Physics 185, another Directed Studies course, the student scholars utilized Computer Software, Planet Hunters, and other methodologies to detect Exoplanets; collected data over 4 months to determine of how likely we are to detect an exoplanet.  

Another Directed Studies course the S-STEM students undertook was Chemistry 285, a Nanotechnology class. Nanotech is one the most powerful engine of innovation, proposing breakthrough solutions to long-standing, real-world problems. Topics covered include: Imaging and Optical Microscopy, Imaging at the Nanoscale and Size-dependent properties of nanomaterials. These kinds of classes are uncommon in regular programs in community colleges in the state.

Post our RRMT program the college continues to support us to offer these Directed Studies courses. One of my students, who is now in the nanotech class expressed his appreciation that a community college can offer such a class and stated “being able to see electron microscopes and using them remotely has been really awesome and motivating”.

Student presentations at Friday STEM Symposia have contributed greatly to improved bearing and confidence when making presentations. In addition to student presentations, the Friday STEM Symposia series has attracted speakers on the impact and control of invasive species, next generation power grid technology, slowing cellular aging research to delay the onset of age-related illnesses, converting greenhouse gases to methane as part of a green chemistry/sustainable future initiative, and an exploration of what leads individuals to become scientists. Speakers have been researchers at major institutions (UCLA, USC, CalTech, CSULA) and practitioners in industry (Southern California Edison, Los Angeles County Agricultural Commission).  An indicator of the success of the program is that the Friday STEM Symposia have been well attended, with extra chairs needed, by students who are not part of the STEM cohort of students.

 Student-scholars have obtained summer internships at JPL and CalTech.  At least nine participants have transferred from West to UC in a STEM major.  This is a significant achievement and is another indicator of the success of the program. 

RRMT Outcomes & Evaluation

Through spring 2017, 79 students have been enrolled in RRMT.  After the slow beginning startup phase, and student interest increased, the program has attracted more students who now come asking about the program.

 Information about RRMT is available (1) on the Science Division’s web page and (2) the program is promoted through separate targeted announcements on the college’s home page during registration periods, (3) in each semester’s schedule of course offerings, and (4) through announcements of project activities in the college’s weekly all-campus newsletter and through email blasts to faculty, staff, administrators, and students in the Science Division.

 Applicants submitted an application including an essay and letters of recommendation and were reviewed by the program faculty.  The project eventually have progressed beyond its slow enrollment start and became fully (20) enrolled; the last years of the project we had enrolled 24 students/year! Unfortunately, when the 5-year program came to an end on May 31, 2017, we still had about $142,000 of S-STEM funds yet to be awarded. Regrettably, during our final year, retirements and change in leadership has caused, for a brief period of time, the program to lose its focus. Ultimately, a formal request for no cost extension has been made, as there was sufficient funds to support about 22-24 S-STEM participants for one more year. The College yet to hear from the AIO.

 


Last Modified: 05/07/2018
Modified by: Abraha Bahta
